title: Code of Conduct
text: participants DSCI 310 project, committed creating collaborative, respectful, inclusive environment. Code Conduct outlines standards behavior expected group members ensure positive working experience everyone. applies interactions related project, including class meetings, team discussions, email communication, online platforms GitHub Slack.

title: Code of Conduct
text: pledge : Foster welcoming environment members feel valued respected Collaborate openly communicate ideas without fear judgment Support ’s learning growth throughout project Discrimination harassment based personal characteristics — including gender identity, sexual orientation, disability, race, ethnicity, nationality, age, socioeconomic status, education level — tolerated.

title: Code of Conduct
text: maintain positive team environment, expect participants : Communicate respectfully listen actively others’ ideas Offer constructive feedback accept suggestions open mind reliable meeting deadlines contributing equally group tasks Ask help needed support others seek assistance Recognize appreciate contributions team members

title: Code of Conduct
text: following behaviors acceptable group: Disrespectful exclusionary language Harassment, intimidation, threats Persistent interruption dismissal others’ ideas Refusal collaborate fulfill assigned responsibilities Sharing private information communications without consent

title: Code of Conduct
text: conflicts arise, first try address open respectful discussion within group. issue resolved, escalate matter DSCI 310 Instructor(s) teaching assistants mediation.

title: Code of Conduct
text: participant witnesses experiences behavior violates Code Conduct, report DSCI 310 Instructor(s). reports handled confidentiality care. current instructor Daniel Chen can contacted via Piazza messaging. participating project, members agree abide Code Conduct.

title: Contributing to the project
text: welcome contributions project!

title: Contributing to the project
text: notice bug, feature request, please open issue . submitting issue, include much relevant information possible, : - clear description problem request - Steps reproduce issue (applicable)

title: Contributing to the project
text: ’d like contribute feature bug fix, can fork repo submit pull request. review pull requests within 7 days.

title: Contributing to the project
text: Ensure code follows project’s coding standards best practices. Include clear description changes reason contribution. Reference related issues pull request description (e.g., “Fixes #123”). responsive feedback make requested changes promptly.

title: Contributing to the project
text: project prioritizes inclusivity respect. contributors must abide code conduct.

title: Introduction to predictcarcategory
text: predictcarcategory package provides tools exploratory analysis predictive modeling related car evaluation categories. package includes functions generate bar plots categorical features, train random forest models, visualize confusion matrices. vignette provides full example using predictcarcategory package.

title: Introduction to predictcarcategory
text: begin creating sample data frame
code: df <- data.frame(   buying = c("vhigh", "vhigh", "vhigh", "vhigh", "vhigh", "low", "med", "low", "med"),   maint = c("vhigh", "vhigh", "vhigh", "vhigh", "vhigh", "low", "low", "med", "med"),   doors = c("2", "2", "2", "2", "2", "3", "3", "4", "5more"),   persons = c("2", "2", "2", "2", "2", "4", "4", "more", "more"),   lug_boot = c("small", "small", "small", "med", "med", "big", "big", "med", "small"),   safety = c("low", "med", "high", "low", "med", "high", "low", "med", "high"),   class = c("unacc", "unacc", "acc", "good", "vgood", "acc", "good", "vgood", "unacc") )  df #>   buying maint doors persons lug_boot safety class #> 1  vhigh vhigh     2       2    small    low unacc #> 2  vhigh vhigh     2       2    small    med unacc #> 3  vhigh vhigh     2       2    small   high   acc #> 4  vhigh vhigh     2       2      med    low  good #> 5  vhigh vhigh     2       2      med    med vgood #> 6    low   low     3       4      big   high   acc #> 7    med   low     3       4      big    low  good #> 8    low   med     4    more      med    med vgood #> 9    med   med 5more    more    small   high unacc

what: 3. Generate a list of bar plot for the target variable against categorical variables
title: Introduction to predictcarcategory
code: category_features <- c("buying", "maint", "doors", "persons", "lug_boot", "safety") plot_list <- generate_feature_barplots(data = df, features = category_features) plot_list #> [[1]] #>  #> [[2]] #>  #> [[3]] #>  #> [[4]] #>  #> [[5]] #>  #> [[6]]

what: Predict Car Categories Using Machine Learning Models
title: Predict Car Categories Using Machine Learning Models
text: goal predictcarcategory provide tools exploratory analysis predictive modeling related car evaluation categories. package includes functions generate bar plots categorical features, train random forest models, visualize confusion matrices.

title: Predict Car Categories Using Machine Learning Models
text: can install development version predictcarcategory GitHub :

title: Predict Car Categories Using Machine Learning Models
text: common task dealing car data involves creating bar plot one categorical variable, creating list bar plots comparing categorical features class target variable, training testing random forest model creating heatmap visualize confusion matrix. functions like generate_barplot(), generate_feature_plots(), analysis_model() generate_confusion_matrix_heatmap() useful. generate_barplot() creates bar plot visualize distribution target variable. makes easier see balanced imbalanced classes within dataset.  generate_feature_barplots() creates list bar plots visualize relationship categorical variables target variable. makes easier identify trends patterns.
code: library(predictcarcategory)  # Sample dataset df <- data.frame(   buying = c("vhigh", "vhigh", "vhigh", "vhigh", "vhigh", "low", "med", "low", "med"),   maint = c("vhigh", "vhigh", "vhigh", "vhigh", "vhigh", "low", "low", "med", "med"),   doors = c("2", "2", "2", "2", "2", "3", "3", "4", "5more"),   persons = c("2", "2", "2", "2", "2", "4", "4", "more", "more"),   lug_boot = c("small", "small", "small", "med", "med", "big", "big", "med", "small"),   safety = c("low", "med", "high", "low", "med", "high", "low", "med", "high"),   class = c("unacc", "unacc", "acc", "good", "vgood", "acc", "good", "vgood", "unacc") )  generate_barplot(dataset = df, x = "class", x_name = "Class") category_features <- c("buying", "maint", "doors", "persons", "lug_boot", "safety") plot_list <- generate_feature_barplots(data = df, features = category_features) # Display the first and second plot as an example plot_list[[1]] plot_list[[5]]

what: Position in the R Package Ecosystem
title: Predict Car Categories Using Machine Learning Models
text: predictcarcategory package specialized tool R ecosystem designed streamline exploratory data analysis (EDA) predictive modeling car evaluation classification problems. provides easy--use functions visualizing categorical data, training random forest models, evaluating model performance. general-purpose EDA packages (e.g., ggplot2, dplyr) machine learning packages (e.g., caret, randomForest) offer broader tools kinds datasets tasks, predictcarcategory specifically geared towards classification problems. streamlines workflow data exploration model evaluation minimal user effort.

title: Create a bar plot — generate_barplot
text: Create bar plots visualize distribution categorical variable data frame. ensures input dataset valid selected column factor plotting.

title: Create a bar plot — generate_barplot
text: dataset data frame containing categorical variable. x name column visualized (string). x_name user-friendly label x-axis.

title: Create a bar plot — generate_barplot
text: ggplot2 object displaying bar plot.

title: Create a bar plot — generate_barplot
code: # example code # example code df <- data.frame(     buying = c("vhigh", "vhigh", "vhigh", "vhigh", "vhigh", "low", "med", "low", "med"),     maint = c("vhigh", "vhigh", "vhigh", "vhigh", "vhigh", "low", "low", "med", "med"),     doors = c("2", "2", "2", "2", "2", "3", "3", "4", "5more"),     persons = c("2", "2", "2", "2", "2", "4", "4", "more", "more"),     lug_boot = c("small", "small", "small", "med", "med", "big", "big", "med", "small"),     safety = c("low", "med", "high", "low", "med", "high", "low", "med", "high"),     class = c("unacc", "unacc", "acc", "good", "vgood", "acc", "good", "vgood", "unacc") )  plot <- generate_barplot(dataset = df, x = "class", x_name = "Class")  if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ barplot <- generate_barplot(dataset = df, x = "class", x_name = class)  } # }

what: Generate a list of barplots for cateforical features against class — generate_feature_barplots
title: Generate a list of barplots for cateforical features against class — generate_feature_barplots
text: function  creates eries bar plots visualize relationship specified cateforical features target class variable given dataset. plot displays count observations per feature category, grouped class.

title: Generate a list of barplots for cateforical features against class — generate_feature_barplots
Generate a list of barplots for cateforical features against class — generate_feature_barplots
text: data data frame containing target class variable features list categorical features

title: Generate a list of barplots for cateforical features against class — generate_feature_barplots
text: list ggplot objects, corresponding one specified features.

title: Generate a list of barplots for cateforical features against class — generate_feature_barplots
code: # example code df <- data.frame(     buying = c("vhigh", "vhigh", "vhigh", "vhigh", "vhigh", "low", "med", "low", "med"),     maint = c("vhigh", "vhigh", "vhigh", "vhigh", "vhigh", "low", "low", "med", "med"),     doors = c("2", "2", "2", "2", "2", "3", "3", "4", "5more"),     persons = c("2", "2", "2", "2", "2", "4", "4", "more", "more"),     lug_boot = c("small", "small", "small", "med", "med", "big", "big", "med", "small"),     safety = c("low", "med", "high", "low", "med", "high", "low", "med", "high"),     class = c("unacc", "unacc", "acc", "good", "vgood", "acc", "good", "vgood", "unacc") )  category_features <- c("buying", "maint", "doors", "persons", "lug_boot", "safety") plots <- generate_feature_barplots(data = df, features = category_features)
